title: 115_s2614
content: The Act may be cited as the "Conservation Reserve Program Improvement and Rural Water Systems Access Act of 2018." It includes improvements to the Conservation Reserve Program. The Food Security Act of 1985 is amended to extend the deadline to 2023. The definition of species of economic significance is clarified within the Act. The Food Security Act of 1985 is amended to extend the deadline to 2023 and clarify the definition of species of economic significance. The Secretary and Governor verify economic contributions from hunting activities for habitat maintenance. Designation of special economic sensitivity areas and priorities is outlined. The amendment includes criteria for designating eligible areas with declining habitat for species of economic significance. It also specifies requirements for habitat maintenance and water quality benefits. The amendment aims to maximize declining habitat for species of economic significance and water quality benefits in designated areas. It also includes provisions for habitat maintenance and water quality benefits. The Food Security Act of 1985 is amended to include the cost of fencing and water distribution practices for interest. Additionally, harvesting and grazing practices are revised to maximize habitat for species and water quality benefits in designated areas. The Food Security Act of 1985 is amended to include provisions for harvesting and grazing practices in designated areas, limiting the amount of acres that can be harvested in a year. Grazing outside the normal grazing period is also addressed to improve habitat for species and water quality benefits. The Food Security Act of 1985 is amended to allow mechanical harvesting of vegetative cover and grazing in designated areas. Harvesting is limited to once every 3 years with a 25% reduction in annual rental rate. Grazing is permitted outside the normal grazing period to improve habitat and water quality. The Food Security Act of 1985 is amended to allow harvesting and grazing on land under the conservation reserve program. Harvesting is limited to 25% of normal capacity with a 25% reduction in rental rate, while grazing is permitted to improve habitat and water quality. The Secretary, in coordination with the State Technical Committee, may prohibit harvesting or grazing on land under the conservation reserve program if it would cause long-term damage to vegetative cover. SEC. 3. RIGHT-OF-WAY. Section 504(g) of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 is amended to address right-of-way issues, including payment, waiver of rentals, and reimbursement of costs by the Secretary. The Secretary is amending Section 504(g) of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 to address right-of-way issues, including payment, waiver of rentals, and reimbursement of costs. The Secretary is amending Section 504(g) of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 to address right-of-way issues, including reimbursement of costs for rights-of-way granted to Federal entities. The Secretary is amending Section 504(g) of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 to address right-of-way issues, including reimbursement of costs for rights-of-way granted to Federal entities. The amendments involve designating subparagraphs A, B, C, D, and E, with changes to nonprofit enterprises and holders. The Secretary is amending Section 504(g) of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 to address right-of-way issues. The amendments involve designating subparagraphs for rental fees for electric, telephone facilities, and rural water pipelines without rental fees for rural water districts or associations. The Secretary is amending Section 504(g) of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 to address right-of-way issues related to rural water pipelines crossing National Forest System land. The amendments involve designating subparagraphs for rental fees and authority to require reimbursement.
